titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Heinz Heinemann (d. 2005) was a lecturer at the College of Chemistry at the University of California, Berkeley and a chemistry researcher at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Following World War II, as manager of catalysis research for the Mobil Research and Development Co., he developed the process for converting methanol into gasoline. Heinemann contributed to the invention and development of 14 commercial fossil fuel processes, received 75 patents and was the author of more than a hundred publications. He was a long-time member of the International Congress on Catalysis, and from 2001 to 2004, he served as a manager of the Washington Chemical Society (a section of the American Chemical Society) and as president of its Retired Chemists Group.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the papers of Heinz Heinemann. Materials include: drafts and reprints of articles; conference-related documents, such as minutes, agendas, bills and receipts; a binder of Heinemann's patents; legal documents from a lawsuit between Mobil and W.R. Grace Co.; bylaws and other documents from the International Congress on Catalysis; articles relating to catalysis, houdriforming, and other petroleum refining processes.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
